awd_titl_txt: Probing the Solution-Phase Dynamics of l3-Iodanes and Relation to Reactivity
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamic & Mechanism B Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor David Stuart of the Department of Chemistry at Portland State University is studying organoiodine chemical reagents.  The goal of this research is to understand how the molecular structure and the reaction medium interact to influence overall behavior of these compounds in chemical reactions.  The project lies at the interface of physical and synthetic organic chemistry with eventual applications in health, agriculture, and technology; it is well-suited to the training of scientists in a higher-education setting.  Portland State University is a diverse institution and is well-positioned for training underrepresented students in sciences.  Collaboration between the Professor Stuart's group and the fine-chemical industry will facilitate a more rapid translation of fundamental discoveries into applications by the broader scientific community.

Hypervalent iodine reagents are routinely used as catalysts, initiators, reagents, and oxidants in chemical synthesis because they integrate well with established and emerging reactivity paradigms such as ionic, metal-mediated/catalyzed, and radical reactions. Electrostatic interactions are an integral component of bonding in the expanded coordination of hypervalent iodine compounds and the hypothesis is that they occur during aggregation and Lewis acid-base chemistry with a direct impact on reactivity and applications.  The goal of this project is to unravel the structure and solvent effects that influence solution-phase interactions of hypervalent iodine compounds with a clear link to reaction chemistry. This is to be achieved by synthesizing designed libraries of monoaryl and diaryliodonium compounds, conducting nuclear magnetic resonance and mass spectrometry titration experiments, fitting titration data to binding models by non-linear regression, and analyzing linear Free-energy relationships and reaction kinetics. A deeper understanding of the behavior of hypervalent iodine in the solution phase will be obtained by 1) quantifying and exploiting the Lewis acidity of aryl(2,4,6-trimethoxyphenyl)iodonium salts and related derivatives, 2) assessing the influence of solution-phase aggregation of these salts on reactivity and selectivity, and 3) activation of aryl iodanes with Bronsted-Lowry acids.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Advances in technology and human health and well-being are made possible, in part, through a deeper understanding of chemistry. Figuring out how to make molecules and understanding their properties is an important part of these societal advances. In order to make new molecules, smaller molecules (reagents) serve as building blocks, and other molecules (catalysts) can serve to facilitate chemical reactions. Organoiodine molecules comprise carbon atoms and at least one iodine atom, which is a point of chemical reactivity, and are often used to make new molecules. This project involves experiments to obtain a deeper understanding of a unique class of organoiodine molecules called hypervalent iodine and specifically connects chemical bonds with molecular structure and reactions (interactions) of hypervalent iodine compounds with other molecules.

Several important outcomes are related to the broader goal of understanding molecular structure and dynamics. These outcomes are related to both the role of hypervalent iodine molecules as reagents and catalysts in chemical reactions. Finally, the outcomes described below span theoretical bonding models, mechanistic studies and empirically derived reactivity scales. All of the outcomes involve data-driven research.

One outcome of this project is a better understanding of the mechanism for boron-iodane exchange. Boron-iodane exchange is a chemical reaction that transfers an aromatic ring (found in many pharmaceuticals) from a boron atom to an iodine atom in a hypervalent iodine molecule. It is a chemical reaction that is commonly used to make hypervalent iodine reagents. Mechanistic experiments were used to show that boron-iodane exchange occurs in a single step (concerted) and this information was used to improve the performance of these chemical reactions from 30% to 70% yield in some cases (Figure a).

Another outcome of this project is the development of a reactivity scale for a class of molecule called arynophiles. Arynophiles have an affinity for another class of molecule called arynes, which are derivatives of aromatic rings described above and are very reactive molecules that will decompose (unproductive) unless they are trapped with an arynophile (productive). Experiments that compete two arynophiles with one reference aryne were used to develop a free-energy relationship to rank order the reactivity of arynophiles. This scale is especially useful becuase it is based on empirical reactivity with arynes and includes arynophiles that react by a wide variety of different reaction pathways (Figure b).

A final outcome of this project is a deeper understanding of the bonding that takes place in hypervalent iodine, bromine, and chlorine molecules. The revised bonding model now shows that atomic orbitals that were not previously believed to participate in the hypervalent bond do indeed play a crucial role. The key outcome is that considering additional atomic orbitals in bonding sheds light on previous trends in structure and reactivity that were inconsistent with the old bonding model. Additionally, the bonding model has the potential to predict new reactivity (reagents and catalysts) to make molecules (Figure c).

 


Last Modified: 01/25/2023
Modified by: David Stuart

Image
  • a) boron-iodane exchange; b) reactivity of arynophiles; c) bonding model for hypervalent halogens
